titlestmt.title: PCT 41: The Youth who was a Bony Spectre
titlestmt.author: Coming-Day

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 41: The youth who was a bony-spectre

p.seg: kîtahtawêh ôki nêhiyawak ôtah , - pêhonân isiyîhkâtêw , - êkotah êh-wîkicik , pêyak awa oskinîkiw êh-miyosit , êkwah ôhtâwiya êh-okimâwiyit , pêyakow ; nam âwiya wîtisâna . Once upon a time when some Cree were staying right here, - Place-of-Waiting-for-Each-Other (Battleford) it is called, - there was a certain handsome youth whose father was chief, and he was an only child; he had no brothers or sisters.
êkosi kitimâkêyimâw . So he was tenderly cared for.

namoy âtoskêw ta-mâcît ; namoya : pikoh pisisik êh-mêtawêt , wiyâkan mistikoyâkan êwako êh-mêtawâkêt ;
êh-pakêsêt , isiyîhkâtêw êyakô mêtawêwin . He did no work in the way of hunting; instead, he always played, and what he played with was a cup, a wooden bowl; the cup-game this game is called.

mâka mistahi sâkihtâw ôma mistikoyâkan , êkâ kâ-mêtawêt pikoh êh-pîmakâmêskahk ôma , ahpôh êh-nipât âskaw êh-kikiskahk . He was very much devoted to this wooden bowl; when he was not playing, he wore it on a strap round his shoulder, and even when he slept he sometimes kept it on his person.

kîtahtawê ôm êkotah êh-wa-wîkicik , kâ-pâpiciyit wâhyaw ohci sakâw-iyinîsah , mâka êh-macihtwâyit , êh-manitôwiyit . Then at one time, as they made a long stay here, one of those Bush-Fellows moved his camp here from afar, and he was one who practised evil, and a manitou person.
êkwah êh-âh-atâwêyit , atâwêwikamikoh tohtêwak êh-nisticik oskinîkiwak . Then, when he was doing his trading, three young men went to the trading-post.
kîtahtawê kâh-pîhtokêyit oskinîkiskwêwa . Presently some young women came into the house.

êkwah ôhi kisêyiniwa pôtih nisto tawâsimisiyiwa , mistahih atâwâkanah êh-pîhtokahâyit . It appeared that they were the old man's three daughters, and they were bringing a great store of furs into the post.
sêmâk ôh ôsîmimâwa akâwâtêw awa kâh-mêtawêsit . At once he who was addicted to that game took a fancy to the youngest woman.
tâpwê miyosiw , nîscâs ! itêw ôhi kâ-wîcîwât . “Really, she is beautiful, Cousin!” he said to those who were, with him.
piyisk kîwêwak . At last they went home.

niscâs , tâpwê mistahi nitakâwâtâw aw iskwêw
itêw . “Cousin, really, I very much desire this woman!” he said to them.

seg.q: yôw , nîscâs ! âyimisiwak êh-macihtwâcik sakâw-iyiniwak ; kitisi-pêhtênânaw mâna .
seg.gloss: “Dear me, Cousin! The Bush People who practise evil magic are bad to deal with; we always hear this said.
Why do you fancy just her?

p.seg: iyâtah_mêyikawiyini iskwêwak , namoya kitâpwêhtên , itêw wîscâsah . When people want to give you women to wife, you do not accept,” said the one to his cousin.
â , nîscâs , mâka nitakâwâtâw ! itêw . “Oh, Cousin, but I am in love with her!” he answered him.

êkos êh-tipiskâyik ,
nôhtâh , maht êwakôw âna nitom kisêyiniw . So then, that evening, “Father, please invite that old man.
ntakâwâtimâwa anihi otânisah , itêw . I am in love with that daughter of his,” he said to him.
ahahêy ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; “Dear me!” cried the old man;

nkosis , tânêhki kacâc nâtakâm kâ-wîh-wîwiyan , êyakw âwa êh-macihtwât , êh-itikot wîci-sakâw-iyiniwa , êh-mantôwit , êh-iskwâhât otôtêmah opawâmiwinihk ohci ? itik ôhtâwiya . “My son, why must you just take a wife from the north, and just from this man who practises evil magic, as his fellow-Bush-People say of him, this man who has spirit power and kills off his fellow tribesmen through his dream helpers?” his father asked him.
hâ , mâka êkwêyâk ntakâwâtâw iskwêw ! itwêw . “Oh, but it is only now that I long for any woman!” he said.
â , cêskwah ! nka-kakwêcihkêmon pitah , itwêyiwa ; “Well, wait a bit! Let me first inquire,” said his father;

êh , kikitimâkêyimitin mâka , nikosis , pikoh t-âtâwêyân , itêw . “But I love and cherish you, my son, and there is nothing for me to do but buy her,” he told him. LB on {t-âtâwêyân}: The word is {atâwêw}: “he trades (especially furs against White Man's products)”; I do not know whether it can bear the meaning I have given in the translation, or how else it may fit here.
êkwah ntomêwak oskinîkiw-sakâw-iyinîsah , êh-kakwêcimâcik , mahtih t-onâpêmiyit . Then they called in a young Bush-Fellow and asked him whether those girls had husbands.

seg.gloss: “They are not married.

seg.q: omisimâw ana nîswâw onâpêmiw ; êkwah ana tastawiyask pêyakwâw onâpêmiw ; an ôsîmimâw namoya cêskwa onâpêmiw .
seg.gloss: That oldest one has twice been married; and the middle one has been married once; the youngest one has never had a husband.

seg.q: mâka mistah êh-macihtwât ana kisêyiniw , niyân ôma kâ-sakâwiyiniwiyâhk êh-kostâyâhk ta-wîcêmâyâhk otânisah .
seg.gloss: But as the old man is a great sorcerer, the fact is that we Bush Folk are afraid to consort with his daughters.

seg.q: nistwâw êh-onahâhkisîmit , aspin mâna pêskêpicitwâwi , iyikoh niyîpihkih wê-wâpamihtwâwi , kayahtê namoya wîcêwêwak onahâhkisîmiwâwa .
seg.gloss: Three sons-in-law he has had, and each time, when off they went to camp by themselves, and then in spring were seen again, to our surprise their son-in-law was not with them.
And so it is not known in what way they destroyed them.

p.seg: iyâtah-kakwêcimihtwâwi , namoya wîh-wîhtamwak , itêw . When they are asked, they will not tell,” he told them.
êkosi ohcitaw akâwâtêw aw ôskinîkiw . The youth longed for her none the less.
êkosi âhci pikoh sîhkimêw ôhtâwiya , ta-ntomâyit kisêyiniwa , ta-ntotamawâyit otânisiyiwa . So he kept urging his father to invite the old man and ask him for his daughter.
piyis tâpwê ntawi-ntomêw awa kisêyiniw ôhi sakâw-iyiniwah . At last the old man really did go and invite that Bush Cree.

êh-pîhtokêyit , ômis îtêw , êh-kîsi-mîcisocik :
hâw , ntôtêm , k-ôh-natomitân , pêyak oskinîkiskwêw êh-akâwâtamâtân . When the latter came to the tent, he spoke thus to him, after they had eaten: “Now, Fellow-Tribesman, the reason I have invited you is because I want one of the young women.
nistw êtokê kitayâwâwak oskinîkiskwêwak , itêw ; It appears that you have three young women,” he said to him;

seg.q: niyân wiya ôtêh paskwâhk k-âyâwâyâhk , - êkoyikohk miyo-atimêw mostoswah , iyikohk êh-ispisît , - êwako kimiyitin , miyiyini kitânis .
seg.gloss: “That creature which we have here in the Plains Country, - then does he well pursue the buffalo, when he has his growth, - such a one I give you, if you give me your daughter.
seg.note: LB on {êwako}: He makes a circumlocution, instead of using the word “horse.” This may be the same word-avoidance as that which I met; the old man is talking, if not to a foreigner, at least to a member of a different branch of the Cree tribe, of a markedly different dialect.

seg.gloss: It is not I that wish to consort with her, but my son wishes to consort with her.
He is not here; he has gone out.

p.seg:
mâka êh-nôhtê-wîcêwât ,
mahtih kakwêcim , k-ôh-isit , itêw . But, wishing to be married to her, 'Do ask him,' he has said to me,” he told him.

seg.q: yahô , ntôtêm , niy âni wiya nikah-miywêyihtên , paskwâw-iyiniw tit-ôtêmiyân .
seg.gloss: “Hoho, Fellow-Tribesman, as for me, I shall be glad to have an animal like the Plains Cree.
seg.note: LB on {tit-ôtêmiyân}: The word here is {otêmiw}: “he has a horse, dog, or other familiar animal”. Probably the form in the text is an error of speech or record for {tit-otôtêmiyân}, from {otôtêmiw}: “he has a kinsman,” and the sentence should be translated, “to have a Plains Cree in my family.” Cf. the next note.

p.seg: tâpwê mâka niyanân itêh k-ôtaskiyâhk ma-manêpayiwak misatimwak , itêw ; Truly there where we others dwell, there is a lack of horses,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “I cannot at this time tell you anything, Fellow-Tribesman.

p.seg: wiya tipêyimêw otawâsimisah ninôtokêm ; wiya kih-âyimihik ê-wîh-ohpikihât , itêw ; It is my wife who has decision over her children; it is to her they gave trouble when she labored to bring them up,” he told him;
mahtih kiy-êtêyihtahk ; nika-wîhtamawâw , itêw . “Let us see what she thinks; I shall tell her of this,” he told him.
êkosi kontah ay-âcimôwak . Then they conversed of other things.

iyikohk êh-kîwêt awa sakâw-iyiniw , êh-pîhtokêt ,
yahah , nôtokêsiw , kâ-ntomit awa paskwâw-iyiniw , êh-ntotamawit kitânisinawa . When the Bush Cree went home, and entered his tent, “Yah, Wife, this Plains Cree invited me to ask me for our daughter.

seg.gloss: We are to be given one horse;

p.seg: mâka kiya êh-tipahitân , ê-kîh-âyimihiskik , ê-wih-ohpikihacik kitawâsimisinawak , itêw . but it is by you I shall guide myself, since it was to you our children gave trouble when you labored to bring them up,” he said to her.

seg.gloss: “Goodness, do let us give her, then!

p.seg: wiyâyêpac wiya otôtêmiyahk ! itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . We ought to be glad to have him in our family!” said the old woman. LB on {otôtêmiyahk}: Perhaps the reverse of the preceding error, for {otêmiyahk or tit-ôtêmiyahk}: “to have such an animal”.

êkos êh-wâpaniyik ,
kisâkamisikê , nôtokêsiw ; nka-ntawi-ntomâw paskwâw-iyiniw , itêw . So, the next morning, “Prepare hot water, Wife; I am going to invite the Plains Cree,” he told her.
tâpwê ntawi-ntomêw . So he went and invited him.
êh-wâpamât awa kisêyiniw , pôtih mistahi miyosiyiwa ôh ôskinîkiskwêwa . When that old man saw her, he saw that the young woman was very beautiful.
ta-kîh-êcik-âni-miywêyimât nikosis ! itêyihtam . “No wonder, I see, that my son fell in love with her!” he thought.

êkwah ê-kîh-mîcisocik ,
ntôtêm , anima kâ-kîh-isiyin tipiskohk , miywêyihtam awa ninôtokêm ; Then, when they had eaten, “My fellow-tribesman, my wife is pleased with that which you said to me last night;

seg.q: têpêyimôw pêyak otânisah t-âyâyit paskwâwiyinînâhk , êh-itwêt .
seg.gloss: she is content that one of her daughters stay in the Plains Cree country, she says.”

p.seg: êkos âwa kisêyiniw nanâskomôw . Then that old man gave thanks.
tân êwakw êtokê mâka , ntôtêm ? itêw . “But which one is it, Fellow-Tribesman?” he asked him.
â , tân ân êwako wêsîmimâwit , êwako kâ-nôhtê-wîcêwât nikosis , itêw . Oh, the one who is the youngest; she is the one whom my son desires to take to wife,” he told them.

seg.q: êkosi mâna mâka , ntôtêm , otâkosiki t-êtohtêw nitânis .
seg.gloss: “So then, Follow-Tribesman, this evening my daughter will go there.

p.seg: pitah kêkway ta-ki-kaskikwâtasiw , itêw . First she will have to do a little sewing,” he told him.
êkosi kîwêw awa kisêyiniw . Then the old man went back home.

êh-pîhtokêt ,
hâ , nkosis , kimiyikawin ana kâ-ntawêyimat , itêw okosisah . When he entered the tipi, “Well, my son, the one you love is given to you,” he said to his son.
awa miywêyihtam ôw ôskinîkiw . The youth rejoiced.

iyikohk êh-otâkosiniyik , êkoyikohk pê-wîcêwêw otânisah awa nôtokêsiw , êh-pê-nayahtahkik ayôwinisah , kikih ocayânisah aw oskinîkiskwêw ; ayis anohc piko mistahih atâwêw awa kisêyiniw . When evening came, that old woman came with her daughter, and they carried a burden of clothes and the young woman's belongings; for, only a short time before, that old man had traded much at the post.
êkosi pîhtokêw awa , tit-êsi-miyikot aw oskinîkiw , êh-kaskikwâtamoht ; So she entered, and they gave the youth what had been sewn for him;
kayahtê miyohôw wiya , ôhtâwiya êh-okimâwiyit . they were surprised at the fine clothes he wore because his father was a chief.
tâpwê wîkimêw . really, he took her to wife.
piyisk kinwêsk wîkiwak . They camped there for a long time.

piyisk kotakak ayîsiyiniwak pâh-piciwak , mîna kayâs kâ-nakatiht awa kisêyiniw sakâw-iyiniw , otôtêma ê-kîh-piciyit , êh-ka-kisâtât otânisah . After a while the other people, one by one, moved camp, until it was long since the old Bush Cree had been left as the last, staying on with his daughter after his fellow-tribesmen had moved away.
kîtahtawê ntomêw awa otihtâwâwa . Then at one time he called his daughter's father-in-law.

ê-pîhtokêyit , ê-kîh-ma-mîcisocik ,
yôh , nitihtâwâw , êkoyikohk ôma k-êspîhtâwahk , êkwah mâna niyânân kâ-mâci-nôtatâwâkanêyahk , itêw ; When the latter had entered, and when they had eaten, “Now, my fellow-father-in-law, the time has come now when we others always go out to hunt for furs,” he told him;

seg.q: êkosi mâka niya mîna kiyipah kê-piciyân ;
seg.gloss: “So now I too shall soon move camp;

p.seg: êkoyikohk nîstah êh-ihkêyihtamân , kayâs kâ-nakacipicistawicik ntôtêmak , itêw ; I think it long enough now, since long ago my fellow-tribesmen have moved camp and left me behind,” he told him;
êkosi ômisi ntêyihtên , itwêw awa kisêyiniw sakâw-iyiniw ; “And so this is my idea,” said the old Bush Cree;

ntihtâwâw , pitah nâtakâm nnôhtê-isi-wîcêwâw ninahâhkisîm , ta-kiskinôhamawak sakâwi-mâcîwin , nôcihcikêwin , itêw ; “Fellow-Father-in-Law, for a while I should like to take my son-in-law along to the North Country, to teach him the woodland way of hunting and getting furs,” he told him;
itâp nîpinisiyâhkoh , êkoyikohk kiyaskociwâw ka-pamihikowâw kistimiwâw , itêw . “When we come back to summer camp, then you, in return, will have the service of your daughter-in-law,” he told him.

seg.gloss: “Very well.”

p.seg:
âta pakwâtam ; mâka kostêw ôh ôtihtâwâwa ,
mâna oka-nta-misi-wanâcihoh ! êh-itêyimât okosisah . To be sure, he disliked the plan; but he feared this man, his son's father-in-law, thinking of his son, “If only he does not go to his destruction!”
iyikohk êh-kîwêt , wîhtam ê-wîh-piciyit . When he came home, he announced that the others were going to move camp.
pitah nistim ta-ntawâpamêw , ta-wîhtamawât , ta-pêhikoyêk , itêw . “My daughter-in-law had better first go see them and tell them to wait for you,” he told them.
êkosi wayawîw aw oskinîkiskwêw . So then the young woman left the tipi.

seg.gloss: “Oh, my son, it is a dangerous place where you are to stay with your wife's people.
We hear that your father-in-law is a sorcerer and a person of manitou power.
Do for a time give up your game.

p.seg: itâp iyikohk takosiniyini ôtê , kika-ma-mêtawân , itêw ; When you come back here, you may play as much as you like,” he told him;

seg.gloss: “Do your utmost not to anger your father in-law.

p.seg: âhkamêyimoh , iskoh kaskihtâyan , kîkway ta-kakwê-nipahtâyan , itêw okosisah ; Gather your energies, as far as you are able, and make an effort to kill things,” he told his son;
ât âni kisâkihitin ; mâka nikostâw kimanâcimâkan , êh-manâh-kisiwâhak , itêw . “I hate to let you go; but I fear your father-in-law, and should dread to displease him,” he said to him.
tâpwê wawêyîwak , êh-wîh-picicik . Accordingly they made themselves ready to move camp.
tâpwê nîswayak isi sipwêhtêwak . And so in two different directions they went from there.
êkwah awa sakâw-iyiniw sipwêhtahêw onahâhkisîmah . The Bush Cree took his son-in-law away with him.
â , miywêyihtam awa kisêyiniw . Oh, the old man liked that.

iyikohk nâtakâm êh-ayâcik , êkoyikohk ati-mâh-mâcîw awa kisêyiniw , êh-wîcêwât onahâhkisîma , ê-kiskinôhamawât tânisi tit-êsi-mitihtâyit pisiskiwah . As soon as they were in the wooded country, the old man kept hunting as they went on, taking his son-in-law with him and teaching him to track the game.
piyisk nakacihtâw ôw oskinîkiw . In time the young man became skilled.
hâ , pêyakôw êkwah , êh-mâh-mâcît , môswah êh-mâcîtotawât , nanâtohk pisiskiwah êh-nôcihât . So now he went alone, as he continued to hunt, hunting moose and pursuing all kinds of game.

êkâh miyâcîci , kîtahtawêh mâna ,
mêtawêtân ! êh-itikot owîkimâkana , min ôhi wîtimwah êh-pakêsîcik , piyisk miywêyihtamwak ôk ôskinîkiskwêwak . When he was not hunting, presently always, “Let us play!” his wife would say to him, and then they, as well as his sisters-in-law, would play the cup-game, until, in time, those young women became fond of it.
âta wiyah namoya tahkih êyisâc êh-pônihtât mâna aw oskinîkiw . Indeed, the young man was always loth to cease from it.

piyisk êh-atih-piponiyik ,
hâh , êkoyikohk ôma êspîhtâwahkih , êkotê kâ-mawacihitohk , itwêw awa kisêyiniw . Then, in time, as the winter went on, “Now then, the time has come when the band assembles over yonder,” said the old man.
êkwah ispiciwak . Then they moved camp to that place.
êkoyikohk ayâwak nîmâwin . By this time they had food for the journey.
têpwê pâpiciwak it êh-ayâcik kotakak sakâw-iyiniwak . They came to where the other Bush People were staying.
âh , miywêyimâw awa paskwâw-iyiniw , êkotê êh-takosihk . The Plains Cree was liked when he came there.

cîhkêyimik oskinîkiwa , mâka êh-itikot ,
âyiman ânih ! Another young man became his friend, but he told him, “It is a hard thing!

seg.gloss: Why are you staying here with your wife's people?
He is really a hard man to be with.

seg.q:
âtah ,
namoya mistahi nântaw ntôtên , k-êtêyihtamiyit awiya , âsay ê-misi-wanâcihât awa kisis .
seg.gloss: Even though one thinks, 'I am doing nothing serious,' before one knows it, this father-in-law of yours has done for him.

p.seg: mîna nistwâw kiw-onahâhkisîmiw ; ati-misi-wanâcihêwak , itêw , ôh êh-itikot oskinîkiwa ; He has had three sons-in-law before you; one after another they have destroyed them,” he told him, that youth told him;

seg.q: awahê kakwê êkâ wiya kisiwâh kisis ;
seg.gloss: “Be on your guard and try not to incur your father-in-law's displeasure;

seg.q: âyimanohk ôma kâ-wîkihkêmoyin , an âna mîna kîtim omisimâw ê-wîcôhkamawât ôhtâwiya , êh-macihtwâyit , ê-mantôwicik .
seg.gloss: it is in a dangerous place you are, staying with your wife's people, for that oldest sister-in-law of yours, too, makes common cause with her father in his bad magic, and both have manitou power.”

p.seg: êkosi êkwah êkotah ayâwak , iyikohk êh-mawacihitocik , êh-mihcêtisicik , nanâtohk êh-âh-isih-wîhkohtocik , mîna êh-nîmihitocik . So there they stayed, when the band had assembled in great number, inviting one another to all manner of feasts, and dancing religious dances.

wiya oskinîkiw kîtahtawê pêyak wîhkayimik oskinîkiwa , pisisik êh-kiyôkâkot . In time a certain other young man became fond of this youth and constantly visited him. CHECK wîhkayimik - ? cîhkêyimik PROBABLY
mâka ôhi wîtimwa tahkih mawinêhok , ê-pakêsîcik . His sisters-in-law kept bothering him to play the cup-game with them.
ayis namoya mâcîwak : ôma êh-otamih-wah-wîhkohtowiht . For they did no hunting, but were busy with feasting one another.

piyisk awa oskinîkiw k-ô-kâ-kah-kiyokêt , êyako mîna kiskêyihtam êh-mêtawêt , piyisk êh-wîhtamawât kotakah oskinîkiwah êh-ayât awah paskwâw-iyiniw pakêsêwiyâkan . After a time that young man who kept visiting them had, he too, learned the game, and in time told the other young men that the Plains Cree had a bowl for the cup-game.

kîtahtawê mâna pîhtokêyiwa oskinîkiwa , ê-wîh-kiskinawâpahtamiyit ôma omêtawêwin , ê-kiskinôhamawât ; Presently some young man would always be coming into the tipi, to learn that game of his by looking on, and he would teach it to him;
piyis mâna ntomâw êkotê êh-mêtawêcik , ê-kiskinôhamawât oskinîkiwa ; in time he would be invited to come where they were playing and teach it to the young men;

piyisk kâ-kapê-kîsik mêtawêw , nêtê kâ-kîsi-miywêyihtahk pisisik kâ-kîh-mêtawêt . presently he was playing all day and every day, with the same addiction that had kept him always a-playing in his home off yonder.
êkosi êkwah tôtam , pisisik êh-mêtawêt . That was what he did, he played all the time.
piyis êkwah âskawih-piciwak kotakak . The time came when the others, at intervals, moved camp.
piyis êkwah nâh-nôhtêhkatêwak ; ayis ôma kâ-wâh-wîhkohtocik mistahi mêscipayihtâwak mîciwin . By and by, too, they began to go hungry; for in their feasting one another they had used up much food.

kîtahtawê êkwah awa kisêyiniw tân-tahto kîsikâw êkwah êkâ kêkway tâpwê êh-mîcit , ê-kisâtât onahâhkisîma , pisisik êh-mêtawêyit , kîtahtawê nîsotipiskwah êh-mêtawêyit , êkoyikohk kisiwâsiw awa kisêyiniw . namoya kika-nipin ; âta wiya ,

seg.gloss: “When mortal men say, 'Bony Spectre,' such am I; but you too shall be a bony spectre.

She was very unhappy, weeping all the time, for love of her husband, as she was being constantly urged to eat well; but as soon as she could go off alone, already she was in tears.

yaw , nmwâc kêkway ay-iskwastamwak oskaniyiwa paskwâw-iyiniwa , itêw ,
npawâkanak ! When he arrived, “Yah, they have not left any bones at all from eating the Plainsman,” he told them, “those dream spirits of mine!

miton êsah wiyîhkipwâcik paskwâw-iyiniwa ! itwêw , ê-mamâhtâkosit ,
nisâkôcihâw ! êh-itêyimât . It seems they much liked the taste of the Plains Cree!” he said, rejoicing as he thought of the other, “I have defeated him!”

êkos iyikohk itêh êh-takohtêcik êh-wîkiwiht , êkoyikohk kiskêyihtamwân êh-nipahâhkatosohât onahâhkisîma . So then, when they arrived where their people were camping, it was known of him that he had made his son-in-law starve to death.
êkos êh-âtah-kakwêcimiht , namoya kwayask âcimôwak ; mâka kiskêyimâwak ê-macihtwâcik . But, though he then was questioned, they did not tell the truth; but they were known to be sorcerers.

kîtahtawê aw oskinîkiskwêw êh-kakwêcimikot kîmôc iskwêwa , âcimôw ,
êh-nipahâhkatosohât paskwâw-iyiniwa . Presently, when the young woman was questioned in secret by the other women, she told the story: “Because he made the Plainsman starve to death.”

mistahi mihtâtêwak ôki sakâw-iyiniwak ôhi oskinîkiwa , osâm êh-miyosiyit , êkwah êh-kitimâkêyihtâkosiyit , ôhtâwiyiwa ê-kitimâkêyimikoyit . The Bush People grieved much for that young man, because he was handsome, and because he was lovable, even as his father had loved him.
mâka kostêwak ; ayisk mantôwiyiwa . But they feared that man; for he was a manitou person.
êkwah êkotah ayâwak . Then they stayed there.

kîtahtawê êh-nîpihk , êkwah awa oskinîkiw ôhtâwiya itohtêyiwa ôtah pêhonânihk , êkotah êh-wa-wîkiyit , êy-ihtatêyimikot ,
êkotah ta-takosihk omanâcimâkana . Presently, when summer came, that young man's father came here to Battleford, and continued to camp here, thinking he was near: “Here he will come with his parents-in-law.”

mâka awa kisêyiniw namoya wîh-pê-nimitâsiw , êh-kostât paskwâw-iyiniwa otihtâwâwa . But that old man did not intend to come down to the open country, for he feared his son-in-law's father, the Plains Cree.
kotakak sakâw-iyinîsak nimitâsiwak , êh-pê-mâhiskahkik . The other Bush Fellows came to the open country, coming to trade their furs at the post.
êkotah wâpamêwak ôhi paskwâw-iyiniwa . There they saw that Plains Cree.
kakwêcihkêmôw , okosisah otihtâwâwa tânt êh-ayâyit . He made inquiries as to where his son and his son's father-in-law were staying.

seg.q: yâ , pakahkam namoya kataw tôtam sakâw-iyiniw ; itêyimâw .
seg.gloss: “Ho, surely that Bush Cree is doing something not right; that is what one thinks of him.
It is certain that you will never see your son.

seg.q: pêyakwâw êsah êh-kîh-otihtâcik ayîsiyiniwah , namoya kîh-wâpamâw kikosis .
seg.gloss: It seems that the one time when they came to where other people were, your son was not seen.

seg.q: iyâtah-kakwêcimihci tântê tit-âyâyit , namoya kwayask wîh-âcimôw .
seg.gloss: Although he was asked where he might be, he would not tell plainly.

seg.q: kîtahtawê kîmôc kîh-kakwêcimik iskwêwa kistim , êkosi kiy-wîhtam êh-misi-wanâtisiyit onâpêma .
seg.gloss: Then some women secretly asked your daughter-in-law, and she told that her husband had been done away with.

seg.q: kêyâpic mistahi kwatakihtâw kistim , êkâ êh-wîcêwât onâpêma .
seg.gloss: Your daughter-in-law is still very miserable because she has not her husband.”

p.seg: êkosih itâcimostawâw awa kisêyiniw . Thus was the story told to the old man.
têpiyâhk kîh-wâpamâyâhk nistim ! itwêw . “If we could but see my daughter-in-law!” he said.

seg.q: hâw , namoya anohc kâ-nîpihk ta-kîh-pêy-itohtêw , êh-kostahk ayisiyinînâhk tit-êtohtêt .
seg.gloss: “Oh, he will not come this summer, for he is afraid to go among people.

p.seg: êkosi mâna tôtam , kâh-misi-wanâcihâci oskinîkiwa , itâw aw okimâw . That is the way he does whenever he has done away with a young man,” the chief was told.
pakwâtam êh-misi-wanâtisiyit okosisah . He was unhappy because his son had been done away with.
êkosi is-âcimostawâw . So, at least, he had been told.
êkwah ôki êyokw âwa aw okimâw otihkwatimah êh-nîsiyit , mistahi mihtâtêwak wîscâsiwâwa ôk ôskinîkiwak . And those two nephews of the chief's, those youths grieved much for their cousin.

ômis îtwêwak :
nôhtâh , mahtih nâtakâm itohtêtân . hey spoke as follows: “Father, let us go up into the Bush Country.

seg.q: kakwê-wâpamâtân ana kisêyiniw , mîna ta-kakwêh-pêhtamahk tântah nîscâs êh-pimisihk .
seg.gloss: Let us try to see that old man, and let us try to hear where my cousin's body lies.

p.seg: mâskôc namoya katawah ta-k-îsinâkwahk itah nîscâs wiyaw êh-astêyik , itêw ôhtâwiya ; Perhaps things do not look as is fitting, there where my cousin's body lies,” said one to his father;

seg.gloss: “We have now enough goods.

p.seg: êkosi isi-wîhtamaw nisis , itêw ôhtâwiya ; Tell this to my uncle,” he said to his father;

seg.gloss: “When now the people go to the open country, let him go along.

p.seg: mâskôc ayiwakês ta-kaskêyihtam , papâ-nisikatisiyahkoh , itêw ôhtâwiya . Surely, he would grieve even more, if we all went about alone in the wilderness,” he told his father.
tâpwê wîhtamawêw wîstâwa êh-itwêyit okosisah . Consenting, he told his brother-in-law what his sons had said.
êhag , itwêw awa okimâw , tâpwêh nanânis êy-ispiciwiht . “Very well,” said the chief, and accordingly they moved their camps in different directions.
êkwah êh-takwâkiniyik , nâtakâm tohtêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak , ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamâcik ôhi sakâw-iyiniwa . So, when autumn came, those young men went northward to try and see that Bush Cree.
tâpwê papâmipiciwak , êh-ma-mâh-mâcîcik . Accordingly, they moved their camp about, hunting on the way.
wiyâpamâtwâwi ayîsiyiniwah , kakwêcihkêmôwak tântê ta-pimisiniyit wîscâsiwâwa . Whenever they saw people, they inquired where their cousin's body lay.
êkosi namoya kiskêyihtamwân , mîn ôhi kisêyiniwa ê-wîh-kiskêyimâcik . It was not known; nor was it known, when they desired to learn the whereabouts of that old man.

têpiyâhk an îskwêw wâpamâyahkoh , kêkway t-ôhtinamawâyahk , nîscâs owîkimâkana , êh-itwêcik ôk ôskinîkiwak , piyisk kapê-pipon papâ-ayâwak . “At least, if we saw that woman, our cousin's wife, we might learn something from her,” said those youths, and thus stayed about, now here, now there, all winter long.
nama kîh-kiskêyimêwak ôhi kisêyiniwa . They did not succeed in learning the whereabouts of that old man.
piyisk atih-kâh-kîsopwêyiw , kiyipah êkwah ta-nîpiniyik . At last the warm weather began to come on, and spring would soon be near.
kîtahtawê mâcîwak . Then at one time they were hunting.

seg.gloss: “Father, we shall not be back today.

p.seg: wâpahkih nka-takohtânân , ê-wîh-kakwê-wâpamak ayîsiyiniw nântaw , itwêw aw ôstêsimâw . We shall come back tomorrow, for we want to see some people,” said the elder one.
tâpwê mâcîwak . Accordingly, they went hunting.
otakohpiwâwa pimiwitâwak , ayis êh-wîh-katikonicik . They took their blankets with them, for they were going to stay out all night.
êkwah kîtahtawê êh-pa-pmohtêcik , mâtâhêwak wawâskêsiwa . Presently, as they walked along, they came upon the track of an elk.
êwakonih ma-mitihtêwak . They followed its trail.
êyikohk êh-otâkosik , êkoyikohk wâpamêwak . Toward evening they came in sight of it.
tâpwê nipahêwak . Really, they killed it.

êkwah êkotah pânahikêwak , ê-wîh-kotawêcik ,
wâpahk îtâp ka-kîwânânaw , êh-itwêcik ôk ôskinîkiwak . Right where they were, they cleared away the snow, to make a fire for “Tomorrow we shall go home,” said those youths.
tâpwê ê-kih-kotawêcik , êh-nahwacîcik , êkosi ati-ta-tipiskâyiw . When then they had built their fire and were making their roasts, night came on.
êkwah mistahi nikohtêwak , êkâ ta-kawacicik , êh-itêyihtahkik . Then they prepared a great amount of firewood, so as not to suffer from the cold.
tâpwê ay-apiwak . So they sat there.
piyisk pa-pimisinwak ; namoya ê-wîh-nipâcik . In due time they lay down; but they did not mean to sleep.

kîtahtawê kêkway kâ-pêhtahkik êh-pê-matwêwêyik , kâ-pêh-sâkôwêwiht . Presently they heard the report of a gun and someone coming a-whooping. LB on {kâ-pêh-sâkôwêwiht}: Probably read {kâ-pêh-sâkôwêyit}: “the other came a-whooping.”

seg.q: yâ , nisîm , êkosi mâna itâcimâwak pâkahkosâk .
seg.gloss: “Oho, Brother, this is what they tell of the bony spectres.

p.seg: êkotôwahk êtokê , itwêw aw ôstêsimâw . Such they must be,” said the elder.
êkosi pa-pimisinwak . So they lay there.
kîtahtawê kisiwâk mîna kâ-pê-matwêwêyik , âsay mîna ê-pê-sâkôwêyit . Presently again, from near by came the sound of a shot, and again someone's whooping.
êkoyikohk pêhtamwak êh-pê-yôtiniyik . Then they heard the coming of a rush of wind.
kwayask sêkisiw aw osîmimâw , êh-kostât pâkahkosah . The younger was properly frightened, fearing the bony spectres.

ôtah êh-takoh-yôtinipayiyik , kâ-wâpamâcik akâm-iskotêw êh-apiyit pâkahkosah , kontah ê-wîh-pâhpiyit , mâ-mîskoc êh-kitâpamikocik . When the gust of wind reached them, there they saw, sitting at the far side of the fire, a bony spectre, smiling a hollow smile and looking now at one, now at the other.
sêkisiw awa osîmimâw ; nama kîh-waskawîw . The younger one grew frightened; he could not stir from the spot.

aw ostêsimâw , êyako tahkih kâh-kiyipa êh-kitâpamikot , kîtahtawê ,
miyâmay waskawîw , êh-itêyimât , âsay osîma êy-isikâtêsiniyit , kâ-nahapiyit pâkahkosah , ê-yâsipitâyit otâsiyânah aw ôskinîkiw , ê-wîh-sisikotiskênikot , aw ôstêsimâw k-ôtihtinât . The elder, at whom the thing kept gazing every little while, suddenly thought, “Surely, he is about to make a move,” - and already at his younger brother's feet, as he lay, sat the bony spectre, and was drawing off the youth's breech-clout, to leap upon him by surprise; and the elder brother laid hold of the creature.

seg.gloss: “Brother, get up! Let us give him a fight!

p.seg: pisisik mâna k-âcimihcik êkos ê-wîh-tôtahkik , ôma kâ-wîh-tôtâsk ! itêw osîma . That which they are said always to be wanting to do, he is now about to do to you!” he told his brother. LB: I do not know what the bony spectres do, beyond wrestling.
yâh , awas , êyisiyiniwiyin ! pakitinin ! itêw pâkahkos . “Faugh, go away, mortal man! Let go of me!” the bony spectre said to him.
namoya ! ohcitaw kiwîh-kakwê-maskamitin pâskisikan ! itêw . “No! I am bound to try to take away your gun!” he told it.
nîsôhkawêwak , êh-mâsîhâcik . The two attacked it and wrestled with it.
namoya kiwîh-ohci-pakitinitin ! itêw , êh-kiskêyihtahk ê-sâkohât . “I will not let you go!” he said to it, when he knew that he had it fast.
nîsôhkawêwak , êh-mâsîhâcik . They both grappled with it and wrestled with it.

seg.gloss: “Come, mortal man, do let me go!

p.seg: ahpôh kika-wêhcihâwak pisiskiwak ; kimiyitin , mitonih ta-minahoyan , itêw . If you like, you may have easy play with game animals; I give you the gift of killing much game,” it told him.
namoya ! kinihtâh-kakwê-cîsimâwâw ayîsiyiniw , itêw . “No! Such as you are given to cheating mortal men,” he told it.

seg.gloss: “If you like, you shall have full length of life, you and your younger brother here.
Let me go!”
“No! I will not let you go!
“Take pity on my words! Let me go!

p.seg: ahpôh kiwâhkômâkan mistah iyâhkosici , êtotikawiyini , kika-pimâcihâw , itik . If you like, whenever your kinsman is sorely ill, and you are called to aid, you shall restore him to life,” it told him.

seg.gloss: “No! Such as you are too much given to cheating mortal men.

p.seg: pakitinitâni , namoya ta-kîh-ispayiw anima k-êsiyin , itêw . If I let you go, that which you say to me will not come to pass,” he told it.
êkoyikohk mâk êkwah wîh-wâpaniyiw . But by this time dawn was near.
kiskêyihtam êkâ êh-pakitiniht pâkahkos . The bony spectre knew that it would not be freed.
kîtahtawê kâh-miskonahk kêkway êh-pîmakâmêskamiyit ôhi pâkahkosah . Presently the one felt with his hand something which that bony spectre wore across its shoulder.
tahkih sâkihtâyiwa êyako . It was always holding fast to this object.

seg.q: nisîm , kêkway awa mistahi kâ-sâkihtât , êh-pîmakâmêskahk .
seg.gloss: “Brother, there is something to which this creature anxiously clings, something which is slung across its shoulder.

p.seg: kakwê-maskamâtân , itêw . Let us try to get it away,” he told him.

seg.q: yâh , êkâ wiya , êyîsiyiniwiyan ! mistah ânima ê-sâkihtâyân !
seg.gloss: “Oh, do not, mortal man! I prize it so highly!”

p.seg: kîtahtawê kâ-nsitawêyihtahk aw oskinîkiw . Suddenly that youth recognized it.
ayiwâk ihkin , nisîm ! miyâmay ôma pakêsîwiyâkan , kîscâsinaw ôtôyâkan ! itêw osîma . “A wonder, Brother! Surely this is a bowl for the cup-game, our cousin's bowl!” he told his brother.

êkwah tâpwê ,
yâhâ , awasitik , êyîsiyiniwiyan ! êkây ôtinamok ! mistah ânima ê-sâkihtâyân ! So then, “Oho, be off, mortal man! Do not take it! I prize this thing too dearly!”
piyis maskamêwak . At last they got it away.
nisitawêyihtamwak wîscâsah opakêsêwiyâkaniyiw . They recognized their cousin's gaming-bowl.

seg.gloss: “Come, Brother, let us not lose hold of him!

p.seg: iyây-îhkinokwêh , awa pâkahkos kâ-kanawêyihtahk kîscâsinawa opakêsêwiyâkan ! itêwak . What strange thing may it be, that this bony spectre is possessed of our cousin's gaming-bowl!” they said of it. CHECK iyây (IC of heavy reduplication?) YUP and (VII) dubitative.
piyis êkwah êh-wâpaniyik , namoy êkwah wîh-waskawîw awa pâkahkos . When at last day broke, that bony spectre no longer tried to move.

êkwah wêwêkahpitêwak wâpowayânihk ,
nisîm , ka-kîwêhtahânaw , êh-itât osîma . Then they wrapped it tightly in a blanket, and, “Brother, let us take him home with us,” said he to his younger brother.
wawêyîwak . They made ready to go.
ayis êkwah kîsikâyiw . By this time it was day.

êkwah awa ostêsimâw êh-nayômât pâkahkosah , êh-kîwêhtahâcik , piyis ê-wîh-takohtêcik , êkotah ayiwêpiwak . Then the elder brother carried the bony spectre on his back, and they took it home with them, until, when they were almost at their destination, they halted.

seg.gloss: “Now, Brother, go home.

seg.q: wîhtamaw kôhtâwiyinaw : anima kâ-wîkiyahk kwêskâhtik ta-mânokêwak anima konta k-âstêk apâhkwâson ; miton isi t-ânâskêwak maskosiyah ; mîna mistahi kit-âstâwak mihtah .
seg.gloss: Tell our father this: at the other side of the grove from where we camp, let them build a tipi with the tent-coverings of whatever kind they have; let them cover the ground well with grass; and let them place there a large supply of firewood.

p.seg: êkâya wîhtamawâhkan awa ê-pêsiwâyahk , itêw ; Do not tell him that we are bringing this being,” he told him;
kakwêcimiskih , êkâya wîhtamaw , êh-itât osîma ; “If he asks you, do not tell him,” he told his brother;

seg.q: êkwah anima mihkwêkin wêskwâhtêmihk kit-ânâskêwak ; êkwah pêyak wâpowayân êkotah mîna t-âstâwak .
seg.gloss: “And let them spread this red cloth on the ground opposite the entrance; and there let them lay also one blanket-robe.
When they have completed this, you will come and tell me;

p.seg: mâka êkâ wiya ta-pê-itohtêwak kôhtâwiyinaw ; êkâ wiya nka-kakwê-wâpamikwak , itêw . but do not let our father and the others come here; they are not to try to see me,” he told him.
êkosi kîwêw aw oskinîkiw . So the youth went home.

êh-takohtêt ,
tâniwâ kistês ? itik ôhtâwiya . When he arrived, “Where is your elder brother?” his father asked him.

seg.gloss: “Oh, quite near here he was stopping when I left him.

p.seg:
mâka ômis êh-itwêt :
anima kâ-wîkiyahk kwêskâhtik êkotah ta-nitawi-mânokêwak , êh-itwêt , itêw ohtâwiya ; But this is what he says: 'At the far side of the grove from our camp they are to go and set up a tipi,' he says,” said he to his father;

q.q: kîs-mânokêtwâwi , mistahi t-âstâwak maskosiyah , mîna t-ânâskêcik k-ânâskasoyahk .

seg.gloss: “'When they have set up the tipi, they are to place there much grass, and they are to lay on the ground those things which we use as mats.

p.seg:
êkwah wêskwâhtêmihk t-ânâskêwak mihkwêkin ; mîna pêyak wâpowayân êkotah tit-âstâwak , êh-itwêt nistês
têw ôhtâwiya . And opposite the entrance they are to use red cloth as a rug; and one blanket-robe they are to place there,' says my older brother,” said he to his father.
ê hê hê hê ha ha ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw ; “Alas, alas!” cried the old man;
mâna nântaw otisi-misi-wanâcihô nikosis ! itwêw . “It looks as though my son had come to some grief!” he cried.

namoya ! itwêw aw osîmimâw ;
kiyâm kakwêyahok , itêw ôhtâwiya . “No!” said the younger brother; “Try to do the work quickly,” he told his father.

tâpwê wawêyîwak , êh-nitawi-mânokêcik ôk îskwêwak , awa kisêyiniw maskosiyah êh-manisahk , ê-wîh-anâskêcik . Accordingly they made ready, the women going and setting up the tent, and the old man mowing grass to use on the floor.
kiyipa kîsihtâwak . Quickly they finished it.
ahaw , sâsay êkwah , nkosis ! itêw . “There, it is ready, my son!” he told him.
â , nôhtâh , kiyawâw kahkiyaw êkâ wiyah pêy-itohtêk ; mîna êkâ wiya kakwê-pêy-itâpik , itâw . “Now, Father, all of you, do not come there; and do not try to look,” he told him.
êkosi êh-ntawi-wîhtamawât ostêsah , êkosi kîwâhtahêw awa pâkâhkosah ; Then he went and told his elder brother, and he brought home the bony spectre;
pîhtokahêw , wîkiwâhk êh-ahât , ôm îtah mihkwêkin k-ânâskêwiht . he brought it into their tent and laid it there where the red cloth had been placed as a rug for him.
êkosi pa-pimisin awa pâkahkos , êh-akwanahiht , êkwah êh-nâtahk ta-mîcicik aw ôskinîkiw . So there lay the bony spectre, covered with a rug, while the youth went to get something for them to eat.
êkosi piyisk tipiskâyiw . At last night fell.

kîtahtawê êkwah ê-wîh-wâpaniyik ,
nisîm , mahti nâtah pimih , itêw ,
êkwah wiyâkan , êkwah askihk . Then, towards dawn, “Brother, go fetch some fat,” he told him, “and a bowl, and a kettle.”
nâtam . He fetched them.
êkwah êwako êh-pêtât , êh-tihkisahk oma pimiy , êkosi wiyâkanihk sîkinam , êh-tahkikamastât êywako . When he had brought them, he melted the fat and poured it into the bowl, and set it to cool.

seg.gloss: “Here, Bony Spectre, drink this!

p.seg: kimiywêyihtên pimiy ; kitikawinâwâw mâna , itêw . You are fond of fat, they always say of the like of you,” he said to it.
namoya wîh-otinamiyiwa . It would not take it.

piyis waniskânêw , êkwah otôniyihk êh-akonahk oma wiyâkan ,
minihkwêh ! êh-itât . At last he raised it from where it lay and held the bowl to its lips, and said to it, “Drink!”
tâpwê piyisk minihkwêw . At last it really did drink.
êkoyikohk mistahi minihkwêw , êh-itêyimât , pôni-minahêw . When he thought, “Now it has drunk much,” he stopped giving it to drink.
kîhtwâm mîna minahêw . Once more he gave it drink.
kitâw . It drank all.
kîtahtawê êh-mêkw-âpit awa pâkahkos , kâ-pwah-pwâkompayit pisisik êh-kaskitêwâkamiyik . Then soon, as the bony spectre sat there, it vomited, bringing up nothing but a black liquid.
nisîm , mahti mîna pêyakwâw nâtah pimiy , itêw . “Brother, once more, fetch some fat,” he told him.
âsay mîna pêtâw , mîn êyako êh-tihkisahk ; êh-minahât , âsay mîna pwâkomoyiwa . Again he brought some, and this too he melted, and gave the creature to drink, and again it vomited.
êkwah mitoni askîhtakwakâyiw kâ-pâpayihtâyit . This time very green was that which it threw up.
mîna minahêw . Again he gave it to drink.
êkwah êh-pakaskihk êh-osâwâkamiyik . This time, something bright yellow.
êkosi êkwah pônihêw , kâwih êh-pimisihk . Then he left it alone, and it lay down again.

kîtahtawê êh-otâkosiniyik , ômisi k-êtwêt awa pâkahkos :
nîscâs , mahti pêyakwâw minahin pimiy ; miyâmay kiwîh-pimâcihin , k-êtwêt awa pâkahkos . Presently, toward evening, thus spoke that bony spectre: “Cousin, pray once more give me fat to drink; for it is plain that you mean to restore me to life,” said that bony spectre.

seg.gloss: “Come, Brother, once more fetch some fat.

p.seg: êkâ wiya wîhtamaw kôhtâwînaw , itêw . Do not tell our father,” he told him.
tâpwê pêtâw pimih , êwako mîna êh-tihkisahk , êh-minahât mîna . Accordingly, he brought fat, and this, too, they melted, and gave to that person to drink.
kitâyiwa , mîna êh-pwâkomoyit . He drank it all, and vomited again.
êkwah wâpiskâyiw êh-pâpayihtâyit . This time, white was that which he throw up.

êh-kîsi-pwâkomoyit ,
nîscâs , miton êkwah nikiskisin . When he had done vomiting, “Cousin, now I am fully conscious.
niy ôma , nîscâs , ê-papâ-pâkahkôwiyân ! itêw wîscâsah . It is I, my cousin, who have been going about in the form of a bony spectre!” he told his cousin.
êwako kâ-kîh-nipahâhkatosot oskinîkiw kâ-miyosit . He was none other than that handsome youth who had starved to death.

êkosi êkwah awa osîma ,
hâ , nsîm , tahtoh k-âyât kôhtâwiyinaw maskihkiyah ta-pakâhtâwak , itêw osîma ; Then said the one to his brother, “Come, Brother, let them set to boil as many medicinal herbs as our father has.

seg.gloss: Do you tell him this.

p.seg: mistah ôma êh-wîh-miywêyihtamahk , pimâcihâyahkoh kîscâsinaw , itêw . Greatly now we shall rejoice, if we restore our cousin to life,” he said to him.
tâpwê ntawi-sîhkimêw ôhtâwiya . So he went to make the request of his father.
tâpwê pakâhtâw maskihkiyah awa kisêyiniw . Accordingly, the old man set the medicines to boil.

êh-kîsihtât , êyak ôm ôhci mîna êh-minahâcik oscâsiwâwa , êkosi tâpwê pimâtisiyiwa . When he had finished this, again, they gave to their cousin to drink, and now truly he lived. LB on {oscâsiwâwa}: The normal form is {wîstsâsiwâwa}, but cf., a few lines below, {ostâsah} for {wîstâsah}; perhaps a neologism.
êkwah asamêwak , êkwah wîstâwâw êh-mîcisocik . Then they gave him food, and they, too, ate.

seg.gloss: “Cousin, truly, I am glad to live and look upon all of you!
Whatever you say I will do, for you have restored me to life.”

seg.q: â , namoya , niscâs ! kiya nawac pikw êh-itwêyan nka-tôtênân .
seg.gloss: “Oh, no, Cousin! Rather, whatever you say, we others will do.

p.seg: nama wîhkâc kêkway ka-nâtên , itêw oscâsah . Never shall you go for anything,” he told his cousin.

êyikohk êh-miyôskawiyit , êkwah ,
nîscas , êkwah cî kâ-wâpamikwak nôhtâwiy nikâwiy mîna nimis ? itwêyiwa . Then, when he was quite well, “Cousin, may my father and mother and sister see you now?” he asked.

seg.gloss: “Yes, let them come and see me.”

p.seg: êkwah ntawi-wîhtamawêwak . Then they went to tell them.

seg.gloss: “Father, 'What are these persons trying to do?' you are thinking.

seg.q: ôma kâ-mâciyâhk pâkahkos ê-kiy-ôtihtikoyâhk , êyakô ê-pê-kîwêhtahâyâhk ;
seg.gloss: That time when we were hunting, a bony spectre came where we were, and we brought it home here with us;
because the bony spectre had our cousin's gaming-bowl, we brought it home with us.

seg.q: êyakw âna êh-mâh-minahiht pimiy , iyikohk êh-âpahkawisit , êkwah maskihkiyah kâ-pakâhtâyan , êkwanih mîna êh-mâh-minahâyâhk .
seg.gloss: Then, when it was given repeated drinks of fat, when he came to himself, that was when you set medicines to boil, and these, too, we gave him to drink.

seg.q:
êkosi êkwah ,
nipê-wâpamikwak , êh-itikoyêk , êwakw ês âna ,
kîh-misi-wanâcihâw , kâ-kih-itiht nîscâs , ês âna êh-pâkahkôwit .
seg.gloss: And so now, 'They may come and see me,' he says to you, for he turns out to be none other than that cousin of mine, of whom it was said, 'He has been destroyed;' it appears that he has been in the form of a bony spectre.

p.seg: mâk êkwah kâw êkwah âpisisin , itêw . But now he has come back to his natural state,” he told him.
êkosi êkw êh-ati-wayawît , ôk ôk êh-itohtêcik , tâpwê wâpamêwak . Then, as he left the tent, these people went there and really, they saw him.
nisitawêyimêwak , êh-atamiskawâcik . They recognized him, and welcomed him.
êkosi êkotah ay-ayâwak . So there they all stayed.

kîtahtawê mâna ,
nîscâs , ôtah kisiwâk ayâwak môswak . ntawi-nipah , êh-itwêt awa kâ-kîh-pâkahkôwit , êkos êh-ntawi-nipahâcik ôhi , piyis kiyipah tâhcipôw . Often, in the time that followed, “Cousin, some moose are close by. Go kill one,” he would say who had been a bony spectre, and they would go kill one, and so finally, he soon recovered his flesh with good fare.
êkosi êkwah pê-sipwêhtêwak , êkwah ê-kîwêhtahâcik wîscâsiwâwa . So then they set out to come here, to bring their cousin home.
piyis êh-nîpiniyik , takosinwak ôtah pêhonânihk . At last, in spring, they arrived here at Battleford.

namoya itah êh-wîkiwiht wîh-kapêsiwak , êkâ ta-wâpamimiht ôhi , mîna êkâ ta-pêhtahk nâha kisêyiniw kâ-kîh-nipahâhkatosohât . They did not care to camp where the people were staying, lest he be seen, and lest the old man hear of it who had starved him.
êyôkô ohci k-ôh-kâtâcik ôhi wîscâsiwâwa . For this reason they kept their cousin concealed.
piyisk pê-sipwêpiciwak . At last they moved their camp and brought it here.
namoya êkotah ayâyiwah osisiwâwa . Their uncle was not there.
kâwih kâ-kîsih-miyosit aw oskinîkiw , êkos îsi miyosiw . That youth was now again as handsome as he had formerly been.
êkwah ê-pê-nimitâsipicicik , kîtahtawê wâpamêwak ayîsiyiniwa . Then, as they came trekking into the open country, presently they came in sight of people.
êh-kakwêcihkêmocik , osisiwâwa namoya wâhyaw âcimimâwa êh-wîkiyit . When they asked, their uncle was said to be camping not far from there.
awa ôstêsimâw ispayiw , ê-ntawâpamât osisah . The older brother rode there, to see his uncle.
tâpwê wâpamêw . He saw him.
mâtôyiwa osikosa , âsay êh-kiskisiyit okosisiyiwa . His aunt wept, remembering her son.
êkâ wiya mâtoh , nisikosê , itêw . “Do not weep, my aunt,” he said to her.
êkosi mîk osisah miskotâkay êh-mîkisiwiyik , sihkosiwayânah êh-kikamoyit , mîna mitâsah . Then his uncle gave him a beaded jacket with weaselskin tassels, and breeches.
mitâsah pikoh otinam . He took only the breeches.

oma wiya miskotâkay nântaw ka-kîh-itâpacihtân , itêw osisah ,
nîscâs tit-ôskotâkât , êh-itêyihtahk ; “As for this jacket, you will have use for it,” he told his uncle, and his thought was, “My cousin shall have it.” --

seg.q: hâ , nisisê , kisiwâk ôm ôtah niwîkinân .
seg.gloss: “Now, uncle, we are camping close by here.

p.seg: êh-pê-ntomitân , wâpahkih ta-pêy-ispiciyan , itêw . I have come to invite you to move your camp there tomorrow,” he told him.
namoya wîhtamawêw êh-pimâtisiyit wîscâsah . He did not tell him that his cousin was alive.
êkos îsi kîwêpayiw . Thereupon he rode back.
êh-tipiskâk takosin . He arrived at nightfall.
âcimostawêw wîscâsah . He told his cousin what he had done.

seg.gloss: “I have seen your father and his people.

p.seg: wâpahkih ôtah ta-pâpiciwak , itêw ; Tomorrow they will move their camp here,” he told him;
namoya niwîhtamawâwak êh-pimâtisiyin , itêw . “I did not tell them that you are alive,” he told him.
êkwah tâpwê êh-wâpaniyik pâpiciyiwa . Then really, the next day, the others came with their camp.
kisiwâk kapêsiyiwa . They encamped close by.
mâtôwak êh-wâpamâcik . They wept when they saw them.
yâ , nicâhkos , kâya mâtok ! itêw ocâhkosah . “Oh, Sister-in-Law, do not weep!” said the woman to her sister-in-law.
kîskowêyiwa . They ceased lamenting.
êkwah wiskwâhtêmihk pimisin aw oskinîkiw , êh-wêwêkisihk . Opposite the entranceway lay that youth, wrapped in a covering.
hâw , ôtah ta-pê-pîhtokêw nisis êkwah nisikos , itêw . “Now then, my uncle and aunt are to come inside here,” he told them.
pîhtokêwak , êkotê ê-isi-sâwahtôyit okosisah . They entered and stood at the foot-end of their son's couch.

seg.gloss: “Uncle, what would you think, if you saw my cousin?”

p.seg: tapâhtiskwêyiwa . He bowed his head.
nitihkwâh , nkah-miywêyihtên , kîscâs wâpamak itah êh-pimisihk , itwêw aw okimâw . “Nephew, I should be glad to see the place where your cousin lies,” said that chief.
hâ , nîscas , waniskâh ! itêw . “Come, Cousin, arise!” he bade him.
êh-waniskâyit , awîn ôhi , êyakoni okosisah wâwiyak ! When he arose, who was it but, incredibly, his son!
kêkâc kipatâhtam awa kisêyiniw , iyikohk êh-miywêyihtahk , êh-wâpamât okosisah . The old man almost choked with emotion, so happy was he, when he beheld his son.
êkosi mistahi miywêyihtamwak . So they rejoiced greatly.
êkos êh-wâpaniyik , ispiciwak pêhonânihk . Then, on the next day, they moved their camp to Battleford.

mâka namoya wîhtamwak êh-pimâtisiyit ôh ôskinîkiwa , êh-kostâcik nêhi kisêyiniwa ,
mâskôc pêhtahkih , mîna nka-misi-wanâcihikonân , êy-itêyihtahkik . But they did not make it known that that youth was alive, for they feared yonder old man, thinking, “Perhaps, if he hears this, he will destroy us all.”
tâpwê kapêsiwak . So they pitched camp.

êh-wâpahk , sakaw-iyinîsak kâ-pâpicicik , awîn ôhi , êkwah k-âyâyit ôhih kâh-kî-nipahâhkatosôhikot , êkwah ê-wîh-mâhiskamiyit . The next day some Bush Folk came camping there, and, behold, among them was the one who had starved him, coming to trade at the post.
nîscâs , mahtih ntawâpahkêk , mahti kê-wâpamâyêk niwîkimâkan , itêw . “Cousin, pray, go look if you can see my wife,” he told them.
tâpwê itohtêwak ôk ôskinîkiwak . So those young men went there.
nawac kiyipah kâ-pê-pîhtokêyit ôhih sakâw-iyiniwa , wâpamikwak wîscâsiwâwa ôwikimâkaniyiwa . That Bush Cree had come and entered before them, and their cousin's wife saw them.

kêyâpic namwâc wawêsiyiwa , kêyâpic ê-mihtâtât aw owîkimâkana , nîso-pipon aspin kâ-nipahâhkatosoyit , k-êtêyihtahk , owîkimâkana . Even now she had not put on any ornaments, for she was still grieving for her husband, who had, so far as she knew, starved to death two years before.

mayaw êh-wâpamât ôh ôskinîkiwa , sêmâk tapahtiskwêyiw aw oskinîkiskwêw , êh-pahpahkikawâpit , owîkimâkana wîscâsiyiwa êh-nisitawêyimât . As soon as she saw those youths, the young woman bowed her head and wept, because she recognized her husband's cousins.

êkwah awa kisêyiniw ,
ê hê hê hêy ha ha ! itwêw ; And that old man cried, “Dear me, dear me!

itah oka-kîh-miywêyihtêh ninahâhkisîm , wîscâsah kîh-wâpamât , êkâ katawah kâ-kîh-ay-ispayiyâhk ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw . How happy my son-in-law would have been to see his cousins, unlucky as we have been!” said that old man.
êkosi kiyipa ati-wayawîwak ôk ôskinîkiwak , wîscâsiwâwa ê-wih-âcimostawâcik . At that those youths quickly went out, to go tell their cousin.

seg.gloss: “Cousin, we have seen our kinswoman.
seg.note: LB on {ntawêmânân}: {nitawêmâw}: “my sister (man speaking); my brother (woman speaking)” is widely used between persons of the opposite sex; whether the use here, in the sense of “my cross-cousin's wife (man speaking)” is specialized or not, I cannot say.

seg.gloss: Even now she wears no finery.
It seems that truly she has been grieving for you.

p.seg: mayaw êh-nisitawêyimikoyâhk sêmâk pahpahkikawâpiw , itêw . As soon as she recognized us, she shed tears,” he told him.

iyikohk êh-pimi-kîwêyit , êkwah k-êtohtêt awa nôtokêsiw , ostimah êh-ntawâpamât ,
ntawi-ntom , êh-itât aw oskinîkiw okâwiya . As soon as they went on home, that old woman went there to visit her daughter-in-law, for, “Go see her,” that youth had said to his mother.
itohtêw . She went there.

êh-pîhtokêt ,
hêy hêy hêy hi hi ! itwêw awa kisêyiniw . When she entered, “Dear me, dear me!” cried that old man.
mâtôw aw oskinîkiskwêw , osikosah êh-wâpamât . The young woman wept, when she saw her mother-in-law.

awa wiya kisêyiniw ,
êhêhêy hi hi ! k-êtwêt ; But the old man cried, “Dear me, dear me!

oka-kih-miywêyihtêh ninahâhkisîm , itah ta-kîh-wâpamât okâwiya ôhtâwiya , iyikohk kâ-kîh-kîsinâcihikowisiyâhk , êh-misi-wanâtisit ninahâhkisîm , itwêw . How glad my son-in-law would have been, to see here his mother and his father, cruelly deprived as we have been by powers above our control, in my son-in-law's destruction!” he said.
namoya êh-kiskêyihtahk êh-pimâtisiyit awa k-êtwêt kisêyiniw . The old man said this not knowing that the other lived.
êkwah tipiskâyiw . Then night came.
êh-pê-ntomak awa nistim , ê-wîh-wâpamikot osisah , itêw . “I have come to invite my daughter-in-law here, for her father-in-law wishes to see her,” she told them.
hâ , nyâ , nitânis ! wiyâyipac kinôhtê-wâpamik ntihtâwâw ! itêw . “There, go, Daughter! It is gratifying that my fellow-father-in-law wishes to see you!” he said to her.
kîwê-wîcêwêw . She went home with her.

wâhyawês êy-ihtâcik ,
nisikosê , kont âniki kâ-mihtâtâmôwi-kîskwêcik , kikosisah wiyawâw aniki ê-misi-wanâcihâcik . When they had gone a ways, “Mother-in-Law, it is but in pretense that those people carry on as though they were grieving, for it is they who destroyed your son.
ahpôh ôma wâh-mâtôyânih , nôhcihikwak , itwêw aw oskinîkiskwêw . Even when I would weep, they stop me,” said the young woman.
â , nistim , êkâ wiya âtota kiyâm ! itêw . “Oh, Daughter-in-Law, please, do not speak of that!” she told her.
êkosi pîhtokêwak wîkiwâhk . So they entered their dwelling.
êh-atamiskawât osisah , mâtôw . When she greeted her father-in-law, she wept.

seg.gloss: “Be quiet, Daughter-in-Law.

p.seg: kâya mâtoh , itêw . Do not weep,” he told her.

êkwah ê-kîh-mîcisot ,
kîwê êkwah , nistim . Then, when she had eaten, “Go home now, my daughter-in-law.
mistahi ta-tipiskâw , itêw . It is getting very dark,” she told her.
êkosi wayawiyiwa . So she went out of the tent.
êkotê aw oskinîkiw askamawêw . There that young man was lying in wait for her.
êyakô ohci k-ôh-itât awa nôtokêsiw , êkos ê-kîh-itikot okosisah . That was why the old woman had said this to her, for her son had bidden her so.
êkwah awa oskinîkiw itah êh-pimisihk , êh-pimohtêyit , pasikôw , êh-miciminât . Then, where the young man lay, as she walked by, he arose and seized hold of her.

seg.gloss: “Do let me go!

p.seg: aspin niwîkimâkan kâ-misi-wanâtisit , namoya wîhkâc êkosi nitêyihtên , kotak nâpêw ta-ntawêyimak , itêw . Ever since my husband came to grief, I have never had the feeling of wishing for another man,” she said to him.

seg.gloss: “Oh, I shall not let you go!
It is I, my wife! I am alive!

p.seg: êyakw ânima itah kâ-kîh-nakasiyêk , êkos ânima nikîh-pê-sa-sipwêhtân , itêw . From that place where you left me behind, I have come here,” he told her.
ânwêhtâk . She did not believe him.
êkwah nôhtâwiy wîkiwâhk tohtêtân pitah , k-ôh-pê-wayawiyan , itêw . “Then let us but go to my father's dwelling, from which you have even now come,” he told her.
namoya tâpwêhtam . She paid no heed to this.
mâcikôtitân ôm êtah nipakêsêwiyâkan ! itêw . “Look, here is my bowl for the cup-game!” he said to her.

êkoyikohk tâpwêhtam aw oskinîkiskwêw , kontah êh-mâtot , êh-oy-ocêmât onâpêma , êkw êh-kîwêhtahikot . Then the young woman believed it, and wept without grief, kissing her husband again and again, as he took her back to his dwelling.
êh-pîhtokêcik êkwah , tâpwê miton nisitawêyimêw onâpêma . When now they entered, she did indeed fully recognize her husband.
êkosi êkwah êkotah ayâwak . So there they stayed then.
iyikohk êh-wâpaniyik , ka-kaskikwâsôw , êh-miyât aw iskwêw ostima t-ôtayôwinisiyit . The next day she spent at sewing, for that woman gave her daughter-in-law things to wear.
iyikohk êy-âkwâ-kîsikâyik , pê-nâtik omisah . At noon, her elder sister came to get her.
kâsôw aw oskinîkiw . The youth hid himself.
namoya wâpamik wîtimwa . His sister-in-law did not see him.
kêyâpic kaskikwâsoyiwa . His wife kept on sewing.
ta-pê-kîwêyan êkwah ! itêw . “You are to come home now!” she told her.

seg.gloss: “My daughter-in-law is first to sew her garments.

p.seg: kîsikwâtahk îtâp ta-kîwêw , itêw . When she has finished sewing them, she will come home,” she told her.
iyikohk êh-tipiskâyik , êkwah kîwêw aw ôskinîkiskwêw . When darkness was failing, then the young woman went home.
wîcêwêw owîkimâkana . Her husband went with her.
êh-pîhtokêt aw iskwêw , nâwayês kâ-pîhtokêyit onâpêma . When she entered the tipi, her husband went in behind her.
sêkisiw awa kisêyiniw . The old man was frightened.
ninahâhkisîm , kiyâm nika-pimâtisin ! itêw . “My son-in-law, please let me live!” he said to him.

seg.q: yâ , nimanâcimâkan , namoya nântaw kitêyimitn , ê-kîh-âtah-tôtawiyan ;
seg.gloss: “Oh, my father-in-law, I bear you no grudge at all, even though you did that to me;
I do not think anything of it!”

p.seg: tahto kêkway êh-miywâsiniyik ê-kîh-atâwêt awa kisêyiniw , kahkiyaw miyêw onahâhkisîma , mîn êh-iskonât atâwâkanah , nikikwayâna , pahkêkinwa , êh-miyât . As many fine things as that old man had bought at the trading-post, all of them he gave to his son-in-law, as well as the furs which he had kept out for himself; otterskins, and cured buffalo hides he gave him.
kiyâm nika-pimâtisin , nnahâhkisîm ! itêw . “Pray let me live, my son-in-law!” he said to him.
êkosi namoya nântaw nitêyihtên , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “I tell you, I think nothing at all of it,” the youth answered him.

êkos êh-ati-pasikôt , êh-kîwêcik owîkimâkana , ocayânisiwâwa êh-kîwêhtatâcik , mistahi mâkwêyimôw awa kisêyiniw , onahâhkisîma ê-nisitawêyimât . Then he rose to his feet, and he and his wife went home, taking their belongings with them; and greatly worried was that old man, having recognized his son-in-law.

êkwah êh-kawisimocik ,
niwîkimâkan , itwêw aw oskinîkiw ,
tânisi , kimiywêyihtên cî êh-oyôhtâwiyin ? Then, as they went to bed, “My wife,” said that young man, “Tell me, are you glad that you have a father?”

seg.q: namoya ! nikisiwâhik ana , mâna êh-kîh-kitimahisk , êh-kîh-kakwâtakihisk .
seg.gloss: “No! He made me hate him, when he made you miserable and tormented you.

p.seg: nawac kiya nimiywêyihtên êh-wâpamitân , itêw . I am far more glad that I can lay eyes upon you,” she told him.
hâw , tân âna mîna êkos îsi nôcihtât tâpiskôc kôhtâwiy ? itêw . “Now, which ones have followed the same ends as your father?” he asked her.

seg.q: nikâwiy ana wiya miyo-pimâtisiw , êkwah ana k-âskôwiskawak .
seg.gloss: “As for my mother, she is a good person, and so is the sister to whom I am next in age.

p.seg: nimis wiy âna omisimâw , k-êtâtisit nôhtâwiy , êkos îtâtisiw , itêw . But as for my oldest sister, she is of the same character as my father,” she told him.

seg.gloss: “I see!”

p.seg:
êkos ômis îtêyihtam awa oskinîkiw :
hâw , anohc oma kâ-wêh-nipât , kayahtê namoya ta-kih-waskawîw ; Then that youth thought, “Now, tonight when he sleeps, let him suddenly lose the power of moving his limbs;

seg.gloss: let that old man be paralyzed!
And let him lose the power of speech!
Until autumn comes, let him be unable to stir a limb!

p.seg: êkosi êkotah mîna kiyipa otânisa ka-pwâna-waskawiyiwa , anihih omisimâwa ! itêyihtam , êkwah êh-kawisimot . And also let his daughter soon lose the power of movement, that eldest one!” he thought, and lay down to sleep.
kîtahtawê êh-wâpaniyik , namoya waskawîw ana kisêyiniw , êh-nipôwisit . Then, in the morning, that old man could not stir, and was paralyzed.
êkwah namoya nihtâwîw . Also, he could not speak.
pê-ntomâw awa oskinîkiskwêw . That young woman was sent for.

seg.gloss: “Come, see our father!
What can be the matter with him?

p.seg: kayahtê nipôwisiw ; namoya mîna pîkiskwêw , pêy-itêw awa osîma . Suddenly he has become paralyzed; and he does not speak,” one came and told her sister.
namoya niwîh-nitawâpamâw , itêw omisah . “I do not care to go and see him,” she told her elder sister.

iyikohk aw oskinîkiw ,
mahtih ntawâpamâtân kôhtâwiy , itêw . But the young man, in turn, said to her, “Let us go see your father.”
tâpwê tohtêwak . So they went there.

êh-pîhtokêt , mayaw êh-nsitawêyimât awa kisêyiniw onahâhkisîma , kontah êh-cîpotonêyit ,
nik-atamiskawâw , êh-itêyimât onahâhkisîma . When he entered, as soon as the old man recognized his son-in-law, he helplessly twitched the muscles of his face, thinking of his son-in-law, “Let me greet him.”

yahôw , tânsi êkwah tiyôtahk kisêyiniw , konta kâ-ca-cîpotonêyit sakâw-iyiniw omanitôwiw ? itêw . “Why, what is the old man doing, twisting his face that silly way, the manitou Bush Cree?” he asked him.

êkw ôki oskinîkiskwêwak ê-kakîsimototawâcik wîtimowâwa ta-kakwê-pimâcihâyit ohtâwiyiwâwa ,
namoya nântaw nka-kîh-tôtên , êka mâ manitôwiyân . Then, when those young women implored their brother-in-law to try to restore their father to life, “I cannot do anything, since of course I have no manitou power.

wiya kôhtâwiyiwâw manitôwiw , kahkiyaw awiya êh-itikot sakâw-iyiniwa , itêw , êkos êh-ati-wayawît , êh-kîwêt . It is your father has manitou power, as all the Bush Cree say of him,” he told them, and with that left the tent and went home.
êkosi êyako . So much for this.
iyikohk êh-takwâkiniyik , nipiw awa kisêyiniw . When autumn came, the old man died.
êkosi mîna kiyipa otânisa nipiyiwa . Likewise his daughter soon died.
êkosi êkoyikohk êskwâk âcimôwin . Now, this is the end of the story.
